relation: Limits the number of continuous incoming events processed.
Sets the maximum number of rate-limited link-state advertisements (LSAs) processed per run.
Limits the number of summary or external Type 3 to Type 7 link-state advertisements (LSAs) processed per shortest path first (SPF) run.
Sets the high watermark for incoming priority events.
pageTitle: Cisco IOS XR Routing Command Reference for the Cisco XR 12000 Series Router, Release 4.1 - OSPF Commands [Cisco IOS XR Software (End-of-Sale)] - Cisco

TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {682882=Packets destined for 172.16.1.53 are sent over GigabitEthernet interface 3/0/0/0., 496610=If the command is not configured, the default packet size is equal to the interface IP MTU size (if that is lower than 9000 bytes) or 9000 bytes. For example, if the interface IP MTU size is 1500 bytes, OSPF uses packet size of 1500 bytes on the interface because the byte size is lower than 9000 bytes. If the interface IP MTU size is 9500 bytes, OSPF uses packet size of 9000 bytes on the interface because the byte size exceeds 9000 bytes. The interface IP MTU size depends on the interface and the platform. In most cases, the default interface IP MTU value will be lower than 9000 bytes., 41634=The following example shows how to set the reference value for the auto cost calculation to 1000 Mbps:, 1061280=The following example shows how to configure an LSA refresh interval of 1800 seconds:, 1082943=The following example shows how to change the start, hold, and maximum wait interval values to 5, 1000, and 90000 milliseconds, respectively:, 6631=To modify or remove the area, the area-id argument format must be the same as the format used when creating the area. Otherwise, even if the actual 32-bit value matches, the area is not matched. For example, if you create an area with an area-id of 10 it would not match an area-id of 0.0.0.10., 922077=10.1.5.14, 296336=(Optional) specifies the number of in summary-LSAs. The range is 1 to 16777215. textBeforeTable: Syntax Description [unicast] ipv4 address-family no [unicast] ipv4 address-family To enter address family configuration mode for Open Shortest Path First (OSPF), use the address-family command in the appropriate mode. To disable address family configuration mode, use the no form of this command. address-family (OSPF) vrf (OSPF) virtual-link (OSPF) transmit-delay (OSPF) timers throttle spf (OSPF) timers throttle lsa all (OSPF) timers lsa refresh timers lsa min-arrival timers lsa group-pacing summary-prefix (OSPF) stub (OSPF) spf prefix-priority (OSPFv2) snmp trap rate-limit (OSPF) snmp trap (OSPF) snmp context (OSPF) show protocols (OSPF) show ospf virtual-links show ospf summary-prefix show ospf statistics interface show ospf sham-links show ospf routes show ospf retransmission-list show ospf request-list show ospf neighbor show ospf message-queue show ospf mpls traffic-eng show ospf interface show ospf flood-list show ospf database show ospf border-routers show ospf sham-link
textAfterTable: Command History Release Modification Release 3.2 This command was introduced. Release 3.3.0 This command was added under the VRF configuration mode. Usage Guidelines OSPF version 2 automatically provides routing services for IPv4 unicast topologies, so this command is redundant. Task ID Task ID Operations ospf read, write Examples The following example shows how to configure the OSPF router process with IPv4 unicast address prefixes:  RP/0/0/CPU0:router(config)# router ospf 1 RP/0/0/CPU0:router(config-ospf)# address-family ipv4 unicast adjacency stagger To configure staggering of OSPF adjacency during reload,
